file_metadata.title: Localization and Loss-of-Function Implicates Ciliary Proteins in Early, Cytoplasmic Roles in Left-Right Asymmetry

chunks.text: Left-right (LR) asymmetry is a crucial aspect of vertebrate development, but the initial mechanisms establishing this asymmetry remain unclear. While the role of ciliary motion in LR patterning at the node during gastrulation is prominent in mouse models, alternative models focusing on cytoplasmic roles of motor proteins have emerged from studies in frog and chick embryos. This study investigates the localization of ciliary proteins in early frog and chick embryos to test the hypothesis that these proteins play cytoplasmic roles in LR asymmetry prior to the appearance of cilia.
chunks.topic: Cytoplasmic roles of ciliary proteins in LR asymmetry
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates the early embryonic localization of ciliary proteins in frog and chick embryos to explore their potential cytoplasmic roles in establishing left-right asymmetry.
chunks.authors: ["Dayong Qiu", "Shing-Ming Cheng", "Laryssa Wozniak", "Megan McSweeney", "Emily Perrone", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The consistent left-right asymmetry of vertebrate organs raises questions about the origin of this handedness. While downstream molecular pathways are being elucidated, the initial steps remain poorly understood. A prevailing model suggests that ciliary motion at the node during gastrulation generates asymmetry by moving determinants extracellularly. This model implicates proteins like LRD, Inversin, Polycystin-2, Kinesin-3B, and Polaris. However, an alternative model proposes that these motor proteins function cytoplasmically to transport LR determinants within cells before gastrulation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Two competing models of LR asymmetry exist: one focusing on ciliary motion at the node and the other on cytoplasmic roles of motor proteins before gastrulation.
chunks.authors: ["Dayong Qiu", "Shing-Ming Cheng", "Laryssa Wozniak", "Megan McSweeney", "Emily Perrone", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: To test the intracellular transport model, this study examines the localization of ciliary targets in frog and chick embryos before cilia formation. The study focuses on protein localization rather than gene expression due to the potential role of maternal proteins and post-transcriptional regulation in early LR patterning. The localization of ciliary targets in frog and chick embryos is characterized and compared, and loss-of-function experiments are performed to assess the role of cytoskeleton-directed motor transport in LR asymmetry.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates the localization of ciliary proteins in early frog and chick embryos and performs loss-of-function experiments to test the intracellular transport model of LR asymmetry.
chunks.authors: ["Dayong Qiu", "Shing-Ming Cheng", "Laryssa Wozniak", "Megan McSweeney", "Emily Perrone", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Immunohistochemistry was performed on frog and chick embryos using antibodies against various ciliary proteins. Control experiments confirmed the specificity of the staining. Antibodies against Polaris, Polycystin-2, KIF3B, and acetylated α-tubulin were validated for use in frog embryos. All targeted proteins were detected in the cytoplasm of early Xenopus embryos and at the base of the primitive streak in chick embryos, before the appearance of cilia.
chunks.chunk_summary: Ciliary proteins were localized in the cytoplasm of early frog and chick embryos before cilia formation.
chunks.authors: ["Dayong Qiu", "Shing-Ming Cheng", "Laryssa Wozniak", "Megan McSweeney", "Emily Perrone", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: In frog embryos, Polaris exhibited dynamic localization patterns, including asymmetric distribution in some blastomeres during early cleavages. Inversin was found in the cytoplasm and at the cell membrane, suggesting potential non-ciliary roles in LR patterning. Other ciliary proteins, including LRD, KIF3B, acetylated α-tubulin, and detyrosinated α-tubulin, also showed distinct localization patterns, some of which were asymmetric. In chick embryos, all targeted proteins were expressed at the base of the primitive streak during early stages, with LRD and KIF3B showing right-sided asymmetry.
chunks.chunk_summary: Dynamic and sometimes asymmetric localization patterns of ciliary proteins were observed in early frog and chick embryos, suggesting potential roles in LR patterning before cilia formation.
chunks.authors: ["Dayong Qiu", "Shing-Ming Cheng", "Laryssa Wozniak", "Megan McSweeney", "Emily Perrone", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Loss-of-function experiments using AS2 (kinesin inhibitor) and a dynein-blocking antibody resulted in heterotaxia in Xenopus embryos. Disrupting microtubules or actin filaments with nocodazole or latrunculin, respectively, also induced heterotaxia, particularly during early cleavage stages. These results indicate that intracellular motor protein activity and cytoskeletal organization are crucial for LR asymmetry and that these mechanisms function before gastrulation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Inhibiting motor proteins or disrupting cytoskeletal elements induced heterotaxia in frog embryos, demonstrating the importance of these factors in early LR patterning.
chunks.authors: ["Dayong Qiu", "Shing-Ming Cheng", "Laryssa Wozniak", "Megan McSweeney", "Emily Perrone", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: While cilia play a role in LR patterning in zebrafish and mouse during gastrulation, several LR mechanisms function earlier in chick and frog embryos, suggesting that nodal cilia may not be a universally conserved initial mechanism. In chick, gap-junctional communication, membrane voltage asymmetry, and activin receptor IIa expression occur before node formation. In frog, early mechanisms include gap junctional communication, ion flux, LR coordinator, 14-3-3 proteins, serotonergic signaling, and syndecans. These findings suggest that LR asymmetry may be initiated before the appearance of cilia.
chunks.chunk_summary: Several LR patterning mechanisms function before node formation in chick and frog embryos, suggesting that nodal cilia may not be the primary initiator of asymmetry.
chunks.authors: ["Dayong Qiu", "Shing-Ming Cheng", "Laryssa Wozniak", "Megan McSweeney", "Emily Perrone", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The study's immunohistochemistry data utilized antibodies, some of which were validated for use in frog embryos. The localization of ciliary components in the cytoplasm suggests that properties of the ciliary transport complex may be recapitulated intracellularly. The observed asymmetries in protein localization, along with the dependence of localization on cytoskeletal integrity, support the cytoplasmic transport model. The study proposes that early asymmetries are generated by asymmetric transport of cargo, including ion transport complexes, along cytoskeletal tracks by motor proteins.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study's findings support a model where early LR asymmetries are generated by asymmetric transport of cargo, including ion transport complexes, along cytoskeletal tracks by motor proteins.
chunks.authors: ["Dayong Qiu", "Shing-Ming Cheng", "Laryssa Wozniak", "Megan McSweeney", "Emily Perrone", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The results demonstrate that disrupting microtubules and actin filaments during early stages randomizes laterality, highlighting the importance of the early cytoskeleton. The study proposes that ciliary proteins may be components of the cargo complex or elements that nucleate chiral cytoskeletal structures. The cargo likely includes mRNA and protein encoding ion transport complexes, potentially including Polycystin-2, which controls Ca2+ flow and is regulated by pH and voltage. The study suggests that understanding the asymmetric localization of ion channels and pumps may reveal the origin of LR asymmetry.
chunks.chunk_summary: Disrupting the early cytoskeleton randomizes laterality, suggesting that ciliary proteins may be involved in asymmetric transport of cargo, including ion transport complexes, along cytoskeletal tracks.
chunks.authors: ["Dayong Qiu", "Shing-Ming Cheng", "Laryssa Wozniak", "Megan McSweeney", "Emily Perrone", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Frog and chick embryos were processed for immunohistochemistry using specific antibodies against ciliary proteins. Control experiments were performed to validate the specificity of the staining. Western blotting was used to characterize the antibodies against Polaris and Polycystin-2 in frog embryos. Embryos were treated with AS2, dynein antibody, nocodazole, or latrunculin to disrupt motor protein function or cytoskeletal organization.  Western blotting procedures are detailed, involving SDS-PAGE, electrotransfer, and chemiluminescent detection.
chunks.chunk_summary: This section details the immunohistochemistry procedures, antibody characterization, and embryo treatments used in the study.
